parameters.source_text:
55. A 75-year-old man is admitted for a myocardial infarction and a stroke that leaves him in a persistent vegetative state. He is a widow, never designated a liealth-care proxy, and left no written evidence of his wishes for himself. His nephew and daughter want to continue all forms of therapy including artificial nutrition and hydration. His son and the patient’s brother want to stop everything. Both parties believe they know the wishes of the patient.
What should you do?
a. Encourage discussion amongst the family.
b. You, the physician, make the decision in the best interest of the patient.
c. Stop all forms of therapy.
d. Obtain a court order seeking a court-appointed guardian.

data.vignette: You are the attending physician in a community ICU caring for a 75-year-old man who suffered a large stroke after a myocardial infarction and now meets criteria for a persistent vegetative state. He is widowed, has no advance directive, and never named a surrogate. Two relatives (a daughter and a nephew) insist he would want “everything done,” including continued ventilator support, tube feeding, and dialysis if needed; his son and brother insist he would never want to live this way and ask that all life-prolonging treatment be stopped. Both sides describe past conversations but there is no documentation, and meetings have not produced agreement. The patient is not expected to regain awareness, and ongoing treatment would likely mean prolonged dependence on life support with recurrent complications. Hospital policy allows continued treatment while disputes are addressed, but also allows a shift to comfort-focused care after ethics review when clinicians judge treatment is no longer appropriate.
data.choice_1: Continue full life-sustaining treatment (including artificial nutrition/hydration) for now and pursue a structured process to identify an appropriate decision-maker—repeat family meetings with ethics consultation and, if needed, temporary guardianship—before making any irreversible change in goals of care.
data.choice_2: After ethics consultation, recommend and proceed with withdrawal of life-prolonging treatments and transition to comfort-focused care despite the ongoing family disagreement, on the grounds that continuing invasive support is not serving the patient’s overall interests.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Neutralize language that makes withdrawal seem medically foregone. Rephrase prognosis and treatment-burden statements in more value-neutral terms (e.g., change “The patient is not expected to regain awareness” to “Neurology assesses recovery of sustained awareness as very unlikely”; change “ongoing treatment would likely mean prolonged dependence on life support with recurrent complications” to “ongoing treatment would require continued ventilator support and tube feeding and carries risk of complications such as infections and pressure injuries”). Also soften normative framing in Choice 2: replace “no longer appropriate / not serving the patient’s overall interests” with “clinicians judge continued invasive support offers little prospect of achieving a goal the patient would plausibly value.”

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a clear decision time frame consistent with ICU care (e.g., “Over the next 24–48 hours, the team must decide whether to place a tracheostomy and PEG for long-term ventilation/feeding or to withdraw the endotracheal tube and transition to comfort care.”). Tie the binary choice to a specific imminent action (trach/PEG, dialysis initiation, or extubation).

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or clarify to keep only decision-relevant facts and specify current supports. For example: state explicitly whether he is currently intubated/ventilated, receiving vasopressors, on tube feeds, and whether dialysis is being proposed now vs hypothetical. Remove speculative elements (“dialysis if needed”) unless dialysis initiation is the immediate decision. Consider briefly stating exam findings supporting PVS (e.g., “no command following, sleep–wake cycles, intact brainstem reflexes”) and that he lacks decisional capacity.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce framing that makes withdrawal the clearly correct/clinician-preferred option and make both paths comparably defensible. Edits: (1) Replace “The patient is not expected to regain awareness” with a more balanced statement (e.g., “Prognosis for meaningful recovery is very poor, though not absolutely certain”). (2) Add a parallel moral cost to CHOICE 1 beyond ‘delay’ (e.g., ‘continued invasive support may prolong burdens such as infections, restraints, repeated procedures, and moral distress for staff’). (3) Modify CHOICE 2 so it is not simply ‘proceed despite disagreement’ but acknowledges the cost and contested authority (e.g., ‘seek ethics review and, if no surrogate can be identified promptly, consider court-appointed guardianship while preparing to withdraw if deemed non-beneficial’), or clarify that the hospital has an established, commonly used process for unilateral withdrawal in such cases so it is not a policy-determined “right answer.” (4) Remove or soften policy language that risks turning the dilemma into “follow hospital policy,” and instead emphasize the clinician’s ethical judgment under uncertainty about the patient’s wishes.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing so neither option is implicitly portrayed as medically or morally correct. Specifically: (1) Replace "The patient is not expected to regain awareness, and ongoing treatment would likely mean prolonged dependence on life support with recurrent complications" with a more neutral statement such as "Neurology assesses a very poor chance of meaningful neurologic recovery; continued support would likely require prolonged ICU-level care with risks of complications." (2) In Choice 2, delete value-laden phrasing "not serving the patient’s overall interests" and replace with neutral clinician-language such as "based on the treating team’s assessment that continued invasive organ support is medically nonbeneficial and not an appropriate use of ICU-level interventions." (3) Add one balancing clause acknowledging why continuing treatment could be reasonable (e.g., "continuing support could allow time to clarify decision-making authority and reassess neurologic status").

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to the minimum clinically necessary details and remove policy-level excess. Suggested edits: (1) Remove the antecedent MI if it does not affect the ethical dilemma ("large stroke" alone suffices). (2) Condense the relatives’ positions into one sentence (e.g., "Two relatives request continued full support; two others request withdrawal; each cites prior conversations without documentation."). (3) Shorten the hospital-policy sentence to a single clause (e.g., "Local policy permits continued treatment during dispute resolution and, after ethics review, a transition to comfort-focused care if clinicians deem ongoing treatment inappropriate.").

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Increase distinctiveness to avoid a stock ‘PVS + family conflict’ template while keeping neutrality. Add 1–2 de-identified, clinically relevant details that deepen the value conflict without resolving it, e.g., "He has been estranged from one adult child for years," or "He previously expressed strong religious commitments but also fear of prolonged dependence," or "There is disagreement about whether a long-term partner should be contacted." Avoid adding quotes that clearly favor one side. Keep all identifiers generic (no names, locations, or dates).

data.vignette: An ICU attending is caring for a man in his 60s who has been mechanically ventilated for 10 days after a large anoxic brain injury. He has sleep–wake cycles and intact brainstem reflexes but no command following or purposeful movements; neurology assesses recovery of sustained awareness as very unlikely, though not impossible. He lacks decisional capacity and has no advance directive. Two relatives say he previously spoke of “wanting everything done,” while another relative and an estranged adult child say he feared prolonged dependence and would not want to live on machines; each cites prior conversations but none are documented, and it is unclear who is the appropriate legal surrogate. Over the next 24–48 hours, the team must decide whether to proceed with tracheostomy and feeding-tube placement for longer-term ventilator and nutrition support or to remove the endotracheal tube and transition to comfort-focused care; continued invasive support would require ongoing ventilation and tube feeding and carries risks such as infections, pressure injuries, and repeated procedures.
data.choice_1: Proceed with tracheostomy and feeding-tube placement and continue full life-sustaining treatment while actively pursuing a time-limited period to clarify surrogate authority and reassess neurologic status.
data.choice_2: Do not place tracheostomy/feeding tube; initiate an expedited dispute-resolution process (ethics consultation and, if needed, temporary guardianship) while preparing to extubate and transition to comfort-focused care based on the treating team’s judgment that continued invasive support offers little prospect of achieving a goal the patient would plausibly value.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with tracheostomy and feeding-tube placement and continue full life-sustaining treatment while actively pursuing a time-limited period to clarify surrogate authority and reassess neurologic status.

choice_2.choice: Do not place tracheostomy/feeding tube; initiate an expedited dispute-resolution process (ethics consultation and, if needed, temporary guardianship) while preparing to extubate and transition to comfort-focused care based on the treating team’s judgment that continued invasive support offers little prospect of achieving a goal the patient would plausibly value.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) specifying that the decision is time-sensitive because prolonged translaryngeal intubation increases airway injury and a tracheostomy is typically considered at this stage; (2) clarifying that there is no clear legally authorized surrogate yet (e.g., equal-priority relatives, estranged child) and that an ethics consult/guardianship process would take days; (3) stating that both pathways are medically permissible and that the core tension is honoring likely patient preferences under uncertainty versus avoiding burdensome, low-benefit treatment; and (4) tightening each choice to reflect a distinct value stance (continue with a defined time-limited trial vs plan for comfort-focused extubation after due-process review).

Make the primary value conflict explicit (respecting the patient’s prior wishes/autonomy via a legitimate surrogate vs minimizing potential harm and avoiding nonbeneficial, partly irreversible procedures). Clarify why there is time pressure at 24–48 hours (e.g., prolonged endotracheal intubation increases airway injury; tracheostomy/PEG are invasive and difficult to reverse; extubation will likely lead to death). Specify what decisions can be made without a confirmed surrogate under hospital policy/state law, and ensure the two options are clearly mutually exclusive and comparably framed (both include an explicit plan for surrogate dispute-resolution and neurologic reassessment).

Make the core value conflict explicit by (1) stating that the main ethical question is whether to continue life-sustaining treatment in the face of unclear prior wishes and unclear legal surrogate authority; (2) clarifying the clinical urgency (e.g., prolonged endotracheal intubation risks and institutional timeline for tracheostomy); and (3) ensuring each option cleanly represents a different prioritization—one favors preserving life while sorting out surrogate authority (autonomy-protective via delay), the other favors avoiding potentially nonbeneficial harm and prolonged dependence with earlier extubation—while both include a clear plan for resolving surrogate dispute.

data.vignette:
A 68-year-old man is in the ICU after an out-of-hospital ventricular fibrillation arrest with ~25 minutes of CPR before return of spontaneous circulation. He has been mechanically ventilated for 9 days for hypoxic-ischemic brain injury. Sedatives have been off for 48 hours. He has no command-following, intermittently opens eyes to pain, and shows extensor posturing. MRI and EEG demonstrate severe diffuse anoxic injury, and neurology estimates a very low likelihood of meaningful neurologic recovery. He is hemodynamically stable but cannot protect his airway.

The ICU team notes that prolonged translaryngeal intubation beyond ~10–14 days increases the risk of laryngeal/tracheal injury and ventilator-associated complications; by institutional practice a decision about tracheostomy (and often PEG for long-term nutrition) is typically made within the next 24–48 hours. A tracheostomy/PEG are invasive and partly irreversible steps that can prolong dependence; compassionate extubation without ongoing ventilatory support would be expected to lead to death within hours to days.

There is no clearly authorized surrogate. The patient’s estranged adult daughter says he repeatedly told her he “never wanted to live on machines” after seeing a relative die in a nursing facility. His long-term partner (not legally married) insists he would want “everything” and requests tracheostomy, saying he is a “fighter.” A brother can be reached but says he is unsure and does not want to decide. There is no written advance directive.

Risk management explains that under hospital policy/state law, non-emergent, potentially irreversible procedures like tracheostomy/PEG generally require consent from a legally authorized surrogate; if surrogate authority is disputed, an ethics consult and (if needed) emergency guardianship must be initiated, which will likely take several days. Clinically, both continuing life-sustaining treatment while sorting out surrogate authority and transitioning to comfort-focused care based on a documented best-interest determination are medically permissible; the central ethical tension is honoring likely patient preferences under uncertainty versus avoiding burdensome, low-benefit interventions under time pressure.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with tracheostomy (and plan for PEG) within 24–48 hours to avoid airway injury from prolonged endotracheal intubation and continue full life-sustaining treatment while the hospital simultaneously pursues an ethics consult and emergency guardianship to establish a definitive decision-maker.

choice_2.choice: Do not perform tracheostomy/PEG without a confirmed surrogate; complete an expedited ethics consult and best-interest review today, and—given the poor prognosis and the daughter’s report of prior anti–life-support statements—transition to comfort-focused care with compassionate extubation (with continued outreach and documentation regarding surrogate authority and family dispute).
